Soon, coffee isn’t going to taste like coffee — at least not the dark, ashy roasts we drink today. Big producers want uniform taste, and a dark roast makes that easy: it evens out flavors and masks flaws. But now the best beans are increasingly being set aside and shipped in vacuum-sealed packs (instead of burlap bags). Improvements like these have allowed roasters to make coffee that tastes like Seville oranges or toasted almonds or berries, and that sense of experimentation is trickling down to the mass market; Starbucks, for instance, now has a Blonde Roast. As quality continues to improve, coffee will lighten, and dark roasts may just become a relic of the past. Oliver Strand

I would build a keyboard that is completely touch screen based but each letter has it's own unique temperature and airflow associated with it that would make identifying each key without looking at the keyboard very intuitive. There would be a very small fan underneath the touch display of the keyboard and the fan would be vented out into four separate valves that would send airflow to the top left, bottom left, top right, and bottom right of the keyboard. Under each key there would be a different sized hole to accommodate the temperature regulated airflow that comes from the main air flow pipe. Touch screen key's that are more commonly used would have a larger hole underneath them which would be associated with a key that has more air pressure and a slightly warmer temperature compared to the other keys to make identify each key easier.
